SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: AKNOLO DAVK
Address: ANNA H. LIM
Birthplace: SASK.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
Where did you set up Housekeeping? With Mr. Dominance & Co.
Where had you been living before that? Minnesota & Canada
For how many people did you prepare meals? Boarded with some
How far was it to your nearest store? Started store in fall of 1904
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs. at time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $3.50
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None, only hard
Was flour milled locally? No... How far away? 100 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes... Whole Wheat? None... Farina?
Other? Beans, meal, flour, corn, rice etc.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it? Ground wheat with flour grinder for short wheat bread.

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, SASK.

Name: ARNOLD DAUK

Address: AMMANHEIM

Birthplace: SASK.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1904

Where did you set up homesteading? North of Strasbourg, Sask.

Where had you been living before that? Strasbourg, Sask.

For how many people did you prepare meals? 6

How far was it to your nearest store? 25 miles

How often could you visit by horseback? Every 3 weeks

What grocers did you usually buy in those earliest years? Smith & Sons

City or Town of 1904: Ammanheim

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Smith & Sons

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.75

How much did you use Graham Flour? 100 lbs

Whole Wheat Flour: 100 lbs

Was flour milled locally? No

What other grain products did you use? Rolled oats

Corncakes: Yes

Other? None

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it? With hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 5 lb and 10 lb quantities.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? about $2.70.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Imperial.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb and 1 gal.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.

How many cows? 5.

Butter? Yes.

What was the price of butter? $1.50 per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cottage.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly cattle, first.

How did you get fresh meat? Farmers butchered their own.

How often did you get fresh meat? All winter, some in summer.

How did you preserve meat? Cured fish for summer use.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Considerable.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Such as trout, perch, pickerel, bass, and other kinds stripped or dried.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 5 lbs. and 10 cents.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $4.95.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Heinz.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb. and 25 cents.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From the farm.

What was the price of butter? 10 cents per pound.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cheddar.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork, beef, and mutton.

How did you get fresh meat? From the butcher.

How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly.

How did you preserve meat? Canned.

Was there a "beef string" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so, what year was it organized? 1880.

Did you use game? Yes.

For how long? 10 years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Essential.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds of fish used: Trout, perch, and pike.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Our first carload of mixed goods was shipped to New Minneota on July 27th, 1903. The train was not named yet so in the fall of 1903. From then our goods were shipped direct from Winnipeg to St. Peter's colony. I do not remember the exact price of most of the goods sold at that time.

Our first cowherd of several years old killed to get it running again. Forstner was not interested in the fall of 1903. From then on growth was shipped direct from Winnipeg to St. Vital's colony.
